Office of J.J. Jones, M.D. 
Frostburg, Md. May 26, 1890 
Dear Aunties and Grandpa
Your letter of the 12 inst. was rec. and I have started to write to you two or three times, but somehow these letters never got finished. 
When Uncle Eddie was there did he speak of having rec. a letter from me. I wrote to him in N.Y. about a month ago and have not rec. a letter. We were going to try and write regular. 
We have very rainy lately. We had an awful hail and thunder storm last Sunday. The rain came down.

in torrents, the hail broke many windows but  none in our house I was in Sunday School and saw the storm coming  and before the review I  told one of the girls that  I was going home and  so about 5 of us girls  came home I got in  just as the rain  commenced. Uncle Tim  and Dr Jones were talking about the train then so  I went and put it down It will be 10 mo. on  the 11 of June since I came here almost a year. The  time has passed quite quickly to me. I don't know anything about when I will go home. I was wishing that I had  been home and could

Office of J.J. Jones, M.D.  
Frostburg, Md. ______188
have gone to Kan. with Uncle Eddie.

     I owe Cousin Jennie Hughes and Aunt Anna letters and don't when I will ever ans. them I have started so many letters to them.
   I hope you will excuse poor writing as I am in a hurry and my pen is very poor.  hoping to hear from you sooner than I have written. I remain,
   Your Sincere niece and grandchild
          Frankie A. Everett.  

P.S.  I had rather a mishap in cutting this off.

upside down Write Soon to your loving niece.

     Frankie    


Frostburg, Md. 

     July 18, 1891. 

Dear Aunt Anna,

     I do not believe that I could count the number of times that I have started to write to you.
   One letter that I wrote was all ready stamped etc. and I gave it to

our office boy to mail and he forgot it and carried it about in his pocket for over a week and then came and told me.  I was so shocked to hear about poor Aunt Jennie's death.  I wrote to Kansas as soon as I heard but did not

receive any answer.  I am afraid they never got it I addressed it to Aunt Mary.  Was Aunt Jennie sick very long?

   I have the dearest little baby cousin here.  His name is Lawrence Jesse Jones.  He will be four

months old the last of this month. He has red hair and light blue eyes and is very pretty and cute. I do not know where to send this letter so will address it to Cousin Mary. Give my love to Uncles, Aunts & Cousins and some for yourself.

At home
  Aug. 10, 1893

My dear Aunt Anna:

   I was delighted to receive your letter.

We are having very warm weather here now almost a 100 in the shade.

   I received a note from Aunt Mary the first part of the week. She was not feeling as well as usual. Clara and Onie's family drove down last Sat. and we had a very pleasant after-noon. I am sitting on the floor in my own room up

stairs and have on my bathing suit as it seems to be the coolest thing that I can find and still I am far from being cool.
Mamma is sewing and she looks rather warm also.  Stanley told me to-day if it did not get cooler soon that he was going to live in the cellar. Poor little fellow, he suffers a great deal from the heat. You asked how Mamma was. She is looking better now than she has for a long time. Has gained nearly 5 lbs. since I came home, I am the thin one now. I have not gained one bit since I came. I am not usually as thin. I weigh 110 lbs. now. My usual weight

is about 120 or more. I was baptized at the house last Sat. afternoon. Clara and the rest just arrived in time for the ceremony. I also united with the church Sunday morning. It was rather odd that Cousin May and Lizzie Everett united the same Sunday. Did you enjoy your trip to Chicago? Some times I am wild to go and then again I think

I do not care about it. Dr. Jones and Louise talk about going in the fall. They would come here and leave Edith and Lawrence here with us while they are gone. I reckon we would have a perfect picnic with those children and Stanley. Edith is one the the worst children I ever saw but the baby

is real good. I will not be able to go back to College this coming year and I feel very badly about it as it will put me back a good deal. 
Remember me "Uncle Eddie" and his family and lots of love for yourself.
Sincerely.
Frankie

626 N. Calvert St.
Baltimore Md.
My Dear Aunt Anna

  I have written almost everything I know to Aunt Mary but I will try and write you a few lines.  Did you have a pleasant Xmas?  I enjoyed

mine very much- I wish you could see Aunt Louise's little girl and boy they are very cute Edith will be four years old this month and she is a lovely child - Baby Lawrence will be a year old in March and he is very cute and

sweet- He is different from Edith as she has black eyes and golden hair and he has light blue eyes and next thing to red hair. I suppose you have heard that Dr. Griffith was married last June to a Miss Bloom

from New York City. It is nearly three years now since I have seen mamma and I have been  nearly wild and see her. I expect to go north next summer and then come back here next year. I suppose that Claire and

are my cousins are they not and I am certain that I would like them and I wish very that we shall meet some time in the near future.  Please give them my best love.  Is Uncle Edward still in Kansas.  I certainly

would like to see him and Aunt Mate and some of  their numerous boys I can remember Carol, Charley Robbie and Eddie when they were at our house real well. Has Uncle Eddie changed much I would love to see
him.  I have not had my pictures taken for quite a while or I would send you one.  Do you ever hear from Cousin Robert and Jennie Hughes and from Ada Thomas?  Are they well.  I would like to write

to May and Lizzie Everett.  Can you tell me where to write to them?  I must close with much love.

   Sincerely Yours,
   Frankie Everett

February 10, 1853
Dear Anna,
You will forgive me I am sure for not answering your kind letter before, when I tell you I have been sick, & could not write I am under a thousand obligations to you for remembering me so kindly. I know you would write very often if you knew what pleasure it gave me to receive that I thought I was not entirely forgotten.
Is Sarah getting any better? I am in hopes she will write and tell me just how she is when she feels strong enough. I wish she could be here with me.

When Sarah C. wrote me she said that Sissie and Eddy were attending school, but she did say what school they went to, whether they went to your school or to Remsen when you write please tell me will you?
We have about thirty five patients at the Glen now, three of them are confined to their bed all the time, one of is not expected to live the week out, poor fellow; it is so hard for him to give up, life seems so dear. he says he can not die. the Dr. told him four months ago, if he wanted to die among his friends he had better go home as soon as he could for he could not do him any good, but he would not go. he thought perhaps there might be some possibility of being helped if he stayed and he was sure  he would not live if he went away. 
How does

Henry like teaching? does he come home every week? it must be very pleasant be amongst friends. When did you see Jane last? when you see her again tell her I wrote her about two weeks ago, and would like to have her answer it as soon as possible.

  How is Aunt now? I do want to see her so badly. & Uncle to. I have not written to Mary yet. I should have wrote if I knew exactly how to direct the letter. I must close now as it is getting dark. Remember me affectionately to Uncle. Aunt. Edward. & all  the cousins. kiss Sarah for me if you please. 

With much love I assign myself your affectionate

  cousin,
     Lizzie.

I have not had a single letter in over three weeks; dont you think they owe me really to bad the last letter I heard from sister Mary was dated Jan. 9th.

Utica Sept. 23d/56
Dear Cousin,
I hardly know who  to direct this to, but I guess  it will have to be directed to Anna, as I have not written to her, since I left. I have given up ever hearing from Sarah or Cynthia again. I shall hear from you . I know . for you are always so good  about answering your letters. I am more anxious to hear about Jane than any of the rest, "because why" you know but when you do  write, I hope you will not

Ask Jennie if she doesn't want to go to Little Falls.

forget to let me know how you all  are: how Mary is, what Jennie is up to, how often Sarah goes to the village and Perry long line to end of page
I will call it "the top of the hill" and let it go at that, whether Sissie ever lectures  now a day, and if you  are as wild  and noisy  as ever, now be sure and let me know it all .
How I would like to see you all , for a little while, if no longer, I believe my tongue would go off, pretty good speed; I have been just as lonesome "as a dog" all day; Mary has been at the dentist all day, so I have been alone. Alexander was up, yesterday, he looks much better than did the last time I saw him, it is all owing to a beautiful

mustache he is raising, though his health is better than it was in the spring.
Wednesday morn. I did not finish my letter last night, so I will set myself about it this morning. Well, in the first  place, it is a very cold, rainy, unpleasant morning, just  such an one as I do not like, I always have the blues, such weather, here I am seated by the window, near the bookcase, all curled up in a lump. I am so cold, for we have not go the stove up yet; but I hope we shall before I am many days older. "By the way" while I think of it, I want to ask you about that  plank walk; have they done any thing to it and if not when  are they going to? Now do

write just as soon as you receive this, or get some of the others to write if you are too busy, to let me know how you all are, and how Jane is getting along. 
I will venture to send Mary's love, for I know she  would if she was up. please remember me to all my friends, if I have any, in the place, and give a great deal of love to Uncle. Aunt. and cousins and accept a slice yourself from
your cousin
Lizzie

Racine  July 31st, 1858
Dear Friend Anna,

    I suppose that you are saying by this time, that I am about as naughty as yourself.  Not quite  I thought of writing immediately so as to scold you for your delay, but now I have delayed some myself, so I will not say much, only that I forgive you on condition that this is answered soon.  I was sorry to hear that your very naughty teeth had troubled you while at your uncle's, especialy as they had stopped you from finishing

that letter to me.  I have some recollection of that Miss Pierce that was traveling with you I think, some young lady by that name came to singing school with Miss Baxter once or twice a great while ago.  I can imagine easily how happy you must be, now that you are realy at home, after having been thrown about so much.  It gave me pleasure to hear that your sister Mary is some better, give my love to her.  I only acquainted with her and Cynthia.  I suppose that it must make a great difference to have her from home please send my love to her when you write to her, and tell her to write to me, then I will surely answer it.

   Dear Anna you asked me how I had enjoyed myself since you have been gone, Well it is rather hard to tell you, in the first place I had strange feelings (akin to hatred) towards those

old cars, when they were running away so fast with you.  I believe they were going faster on purpose so as to take you out of my sight, then after straining my poor eyes looking after the old creature I turned away from the old Depot, and cried all the way home.  I did not stay there more than ten minutes, for it was too lonesome for me just then.  I went to my Aunt Laura's, sometime in the afternoon the Dr. brought Joe there with his arm all bound up as if it was broken, but it was only some ligaments in the wrist that he had broken it got well in a week or two.

     John James and that other girl did call here Sat. eve week ago tonight and I was cleaning gooseberries, but I did not have many to clean by the time they were going.  You could not peep very long at either of the front windows before I would catch a glimpse at you. 


Mrs. Thomas and the family send their love to you and my little neighbor Annie Lloyd.

dear old face, and then you could not have time to get to the door before this little chick would be clinging to your neck and smoothering you kisses. so you better not peep, though I wish you would?

   I have had a great deal of company for two or three weeks, now there is minister staying here and is going to preach tomorrow he is from Utica and is on his way there now, his name is Owens.
   I dont go down town quite so often now, as I dont like to go alone as well. Aunt Ellen is quite sick now has to keep her bed, but we think that the Dr. she has now understands her case so we have better hopes of her. both her and Aunt Laura send their love to you my little dear
   Mrs. Williams the store has a very fine baby almost two week old, she is geting on nicely and wishes to be remembered by you as an old friend. I am sorry that your Mothers health is not very good, I think that coming out this way would do her a great deal of good. Give my love to her and Sarah, and tell her, that there is a house a little above us for Sal. remember me also to your father and bro. and all. I have not heard from Cincinati nor I don't expect to very soon, I am sorry to tell you that I have not given your love

to any of the young men as I am afraid that if I do they wont care for mine. perhaps I will to a few yet. Charles Lewis has come back and has been getting himself all freckled. I am stopping now. dont scold. with a great deal of love to your dear self Lizzie

too long aint it?

Battle Creek Sanitarium
Battle Creek.
Mich
Dec. 1882
My dear Anna

    In a letter received a few days ago from Louise she told me you had been quite sick but were now better.  I was very sorry to hear you were ill, and do trust you have now quite recovered.  She told me you and Jennie were still at Remsen.  I think of you a good deal lately that the snow has come & covered the country.  I shall never forget the appearance of the country that week I spent with you in mid winter.  It was grand. There has been sleighing here the last few days, but today it is over thaw has commenced. I like the cold weather and enjoy the country and this is essentially country altho there are a good many houses all round

but Battle Creek proper is a mile from here, it has three or four thousand inhabitants, & is quite a pretty little place. this Institution stands on an elevation, and commands a lovely view of all the country round.  I was here during the Fall, & had the benefit of the autumn foliage.  I have been here since the 21st Sept. and have been very ill, for some time.  I scarcely expected I would live to leave here, but I am some better now, but the improvement is very slow.  Of course I do not enjoy being here away from all friends, but I thought it was better to for a time till I was a little stronger, as I dislike giving trouble to my kind friends.  My Chicago friends were very much against my leaving them, & cheer my solitude by frequent letters.  I intended going to England in the summer & afterwards in the Fall, but my ill health prevented my doing so.

I hope to go as soon as spring comes I expect I will be well enough by that time. When I thought of going in the fall, I wrote to cousin Mary Everett asking her if she could help me to get a Boarding House, where I could remain a few weeks before sailing, so as to see a little of New York City, but I received no reply whether the letter was lost, or whether she cannot help me, of course I cannot tell. I have a mind to try her again, as she is the only relative or friend I have in New York City. I have lost her address and would feel greatly obliged if you would send it me. I have also been surprised not to have received any letter from you or Jennie for to long. I wrote in April or May last, & gave my address at 411 West Monroe St., but even if I had not done so, I know Jennie has been to Utica, & if she wished to write to me could have got my address from Fannie.

so I cannot account for your silence in any way. except that I have offended you in some way. I am very sorry if that is the case. And assure you it had been done unwittingly There are about 150 patients here I need not have felt lonesome had I been pretty well and able to enjoy society. For there are many very agreeable people here and as it is I have made several pleasant friends, while I was very ill. Nothing could exceed the kindness and solicitude of some of the lady patients. I had only been here two or three weeks then I was an entire stranger. Now I am  not confined to my room, but am able to go about.  The treatment here is very thorough and excellent, but it was too severe for me. Now I take very much lighter treatment & fare better, I think the  massages & the electricity are what helps me mostly. I have had a good many letters from my Welsh & English friends lately,

they are pretty troubled about me, for they expected me home in the Fall. How glad I will be to see their dear faces again.

  I hear from Cousin Mary Ann very frequently, she is now returning home? as she has her niece Ella Roberts with her. Ella goes to school at Chicago. M A is very anxious to get her back to Chicago as she does not think her improving sufficiently here but I am desirous to give this treatment a little longer chance to work an improvement. Dr Kellogg says I will get well. 
  These people are Seventh Day Baptists we have no zeal dear old Sunday  Saturday they keep very strictly  everything is very very quiet

and it is only by fits & starts through the day we can remember it is Sunday, it is a great cause of discontent & unpleasantness. So people do not stay longer here than they are absolutely obliged to - Did you receive the circular of this place that I sent you? ??all expected to go to bed at eight and I am always ready now. I have benefited much by the quiet & rest here. I do hope you are both well now. My love to you both & to all the other friends. 
Sincerely Your Cousin
Lizzie Williams
N? A wrote me that Cousin Edward was in Chicago. I felt so sorry to miss him. Please give him my love & tell him so      excuse a badly written & badly composed letter. I wrote it last night & was a good deal tired. They want me to go

to Davisville on a visit when I go to New York I will all depend how I am — I would have gone there instead of this place, had their institution not burnt down

Osawatomie Apr 10th 1892
Dear Aunts,
Your letter was received last night and hasten to reply lest I should neglect it as I have been doing for so long. We had a severe wind storm here on the date you mentioned and from your description I think that it was about as hard in Mich. as here. We did not hear of any serious damage in the Country about here. The wind did some havoc in Osawatomie. It tipped the sidewalk from Mr Drydens corner to Lenhards corner over entire without breaking it.
Olive also sends you some easter lilys. 
Mr Robinson & family went away last fall he engaged to work for the same Con. as he worked for before coming here & they are not coming back this summer some think they will never come back they were quite discouraged last summer the money came so slow gardening much too from all to all Libbie

We hear from J Eddie quite often through his father I suppose you are anxiously awaiting your turn for a visit 
We wer taken by prise when he told us of his plans he didn't tell us untill Sunday evening and he started Monday he thought his father had spoke of it while he was at Anthony we were sorry to have him go so far away but hope he can be near you hope he will have good success and be able to come and see us before long & bring his Aunties with him 

  Our school opened Sunday with the same teacher as last term a Miss Kimbal of Paola. Our neighbors are all well I think. Mrs Lerenden has  just returned from a trip east to Elgin to see a sick sister haven't seen her since she came home. Mrs Snyder came to see us  one day last week had a very nice visit. She is a great talker. Mr Walthial & family have moved to town & rented the farm to a man from Mo Olive has picked 

a little sprig from the sweet apple tree & a unclear berry bush both from orchard

Dear auntees Robert has too many chores to do today to be able to write a very long letter so I will gladly finish his sheet. We have a mullato boy working for us this summer "he is a boy at that Sydney Duncan bring it up" he was not feeling well today so didnt help R any. We are milking about 21 or 22 cows now. Betty had a nice heifer calf today our Mary Ann cow had twins this spring we didnt raise either as they were small and came very early. Do you remember Aunt Ro how wild lofty used to be when we went to the barn she is as gentle as  any of the cows now & that is  saying a good deal as they are all very quiet after getting acquainted with us. We did not go to church today it is windy & cold & rained a little this morning.

The wind also did about $100 damage to the osage valley block or (new bank) The building is built of brick with a square roof. Around the roof there was built a cornice about 4ft. high to protect the building against fire. On the South side this Cornice was blown in on the roof. There were several small buildings blown down but no serious damage done. It was a strong wind but nothing frightful about it here. We have planted onions, radish, beets and some other early vegetables.  Grass is beginning to start and some of the trees are looking green. Our pieplant are nearly large enough to use. Libbie has finished my letter 

so I will merely say that we are all well and as happy as need be We are having what I call our disagreeable weather windy and rainy Love to you all  your Nephew R. H. Everett

Osawatomie Dec 6/91
Dear Aunties,
We think it about time to hear from you & I think in order to get a letter I will have to write one. We are all real well, & hope you are the same. 
Are you having very cold weather 
We think we have had some pretty cold weather for this time of the year in Kansas at least. We felt it very much the house is pretty cold a good deal of cold coming through the floor although we had it banked and have you heard of the new bed rooms we have it 
Took a little extra fire to warm

them or rather it as it is in one room yet downstairs & will have a room up stairs when it is finished we find it very convenient as it is. We are making about 9 lbs of butter a day, churn every day but sunday. We havent any fresh cows yet.
We expect to enjoy a good visit from J.E. soon we hope to hear from him to-day
We have two men here now shucking corn geting up wood 
PC I think they are both strangers to you Aunt Mary their names are Jed Cogswell & Lewis Clark
Robert has fixed up the frame horse barn for all the horses taking the partition out where Harveys colt was, making more room and he

also made stalls for them. 
Yesterday we fixed up the old log stable for the hens & got them all in but 4 we will keep them shut up for a few days I am afraid it will be hard to break them of going in the shed to roost we lost a great many of their eggs this summer they like to lay out in the grass we only get 2 or 3 eggs a day now. We are geting 30 cts for the butter yet
There was a spelling school at the School House last night. we all went except Uncle J we thought he would go untill we were ready to start when he backed out It was rather mudy for him he said we enjoyed it very much
Libbie Snyders husband is very

poorly he has been unable to work nearly all summer they say it is heart trouble
Florence Lesenden has been sick but was at the Spelling School last night.
Olive & Lewis have had their photos taken. when we get them we will send you one
Olive has had a real hard time with an ulcerated tooth it broak on the out-side and has left quite a sear we had the tooth taken out
Uncle John is able to get around much better now than befor. The apples are quite good have just the box that is down celler full
I must close well much love from all to you all
Libbie

Gann Valley Oct 20 1890
Dear Aunt Anna
We think and speak of you very often allthough we are not very prompt in answering your letters We got a letter from Mother and cousin Jennie telling of Mrs Huddlesins sudden illness we hope that she is better now Tell her that we want to be remembered to her when you write her She was always very kind to us when we came to see you  Do not try to be to smart now that she is gone we hear that you made pies & cookies "I think" for the meeting I would like to have been there to help eat them

You wanted to know where Robert was the day the Children and I are our dinner on the crust board he was away working perhaps you know the crops were rather poor here this season and he got a chance to work at pretty good wages and so was gone two mo  I was very lonely with out him but it was not so bad as it might have been our house was so near my Brothers The Children are so much company Lewis would talk me to sleep allmoste every night He talks of Aunt Anna very often He wants to go to Kansas to live He says you know Aunt Anna will come out there He thinks Grandma Hughes & Auntie Mary Ann will come there to but Grandma Sleuben is to comfortable where she is to ever leave west You see he has got it all

planed we expect Mary Ann out here this fall in her last letter she said if we don't like Dak we will go to Kan Mother thinks it would be a better place to live she could live as well perhaps in Ossawatomie as in Prospect when she goes to live alone "The Lord permiting" Robert is writing a good long letter to Kansas now we received a letter from J.E. while he was at his Fathers
Aunt Jennice writes us good letters 
R is going to begin a term of three months school a week from today "our district school"
We have fryed chicken most every day Do you fry them when you cook then we par boil them and then fry in plenty butter. "butter is cheap out here we make enough for our own use from our two cows" you try

it they are splendid We could get barely nothing for our chickens if we sold them. & to sell them we would have to take them to town which is 80 miles away
Do your hens lay. there are now two of ours laying.
Is Mary Everett there with you now if Remember us to her & also to Mr Jones
I must close as it is bed time
With much love from all to you
Libbie

Galesburg Dec 20th 1858 
Dearest Annie 
Do forgive my long silence. It is not dear Annie because  I have forgotten you but I have been  very busy studying striving to improve  my mind. You know my dislike to  letter writing and if it were not for  my great desire to hear from you I fear  I should not now write. You wished to know about the Seminary.  Miss Wilcox is the Preceptress  and has about

30 young ladies under her charge.  I believe they are quite well pleased  with her. They have monthly Receptions  and the young ladies are permitted to  invite all of their friends and are very  pleasant I hear. Their rules are very strict  for the young ladies are not allowed  to go out or receive company any eve- ning except Friday. I do not call  at the Seminary quite as often as I did  last winter for I have not as many  friends there now. Mrs Sheppard is  the music teacher in the Seminary.  The College is any thing but prosperous  the number of Students daily  diminishing. I do not know whether  I can tell you any city? news or not.  The streets are just as muddy as when

you were here. We have had a little  snow which I enjoyed very much  in having a delightful ride with  a company of ten. How is sleighing  in New York? Mother is not at all  well she will work though she would  love to see you as well as my self. Grandma  is at Knox Corners we all miss her  very much. The Farnham's family are all quite well they are in their  new house. May was writing me not long  ago and asked about you, and sent much  love. As for my self I am at home and quite  well staying with my friend Katie Blanchard we recite to Sister May who has  returned from Chicago. We study Arithmetic Grammar Spelling and the history  which your Sister Jennie gave me.

I have nearly finished it the Second time. We also read Rollins  Ancient History and study music. Don't you think I have my hands full?  I had a present of a pair of Canary birds, one of them is a beautiful  singer he is charming or rather distract- ing me with his music. Give much love  to Jennie for me and indeed you may to all the family for I almost feel acquainted with them because of my  great friendship for you. After reading  your letter over I find I have not  answered all your questions Mrs Prentice  keeps the boarding house. Nellie has not  returned but nearly all the rest of the  girls are here but as it is nearly three which is our dinner hour I must

Stamped Turin Aug 9
N.Y.
Miss A.L. Everett
Remsen
N.Y.

Turin, Aug. 8th 1867.
My Dear Sister, 
I am going to undertake to answer one of those unanswered letters you have lying in your portfolio. If it is not done satisfactorily to you, I will let you try it next time. I sent a note home with William which I wrote that morning before I was fairly awake and I hardly know what I did write. I hope I did not put any frightful dream in it. 
I would like to know how you are enjoying this warm weather We find it difficult to "keep cool." Have our cousins from Chicago come yet? I am in hopes to see them when I come home. Should be very sorry to miss seeing them. I think Cynthia wrote me when they were coming, but I have forgotten

I think we had better start Tuesday morning, If you would prefer starting Tuesday afternoon please let me know Sat. We are going to have the company of two ladies besides our company as far as Springfield; Mrs. R of whom I spoke in my other letter, and a young lady from Lowville. I hope nothing will occur to hinder us from going this time as it is third time we have set for the said trip East. I hope you have marked out the route you would prefer as I have given it no thought since I was home. Has Mary concluded to go with us. I wonder if she went to the Falls with the Penymynydd company. 
Good bye. I hope to see you Monday morning. Tell the girls to save some rain water as will want my vest and linen coat done up when I get home. From Your Brother

Dear Anna
We received your letter Saturday night, and are very sorry for your perplexity in regard to the piano. Your first letter was received when we were most hurried with Cenhadwr, and as it was several days before our hurry was over, it was some time before we could ascertain anything about the probability of our success in obtaining scholars for you. We were very sorry on your account, but this is our explanation. Saturday P.M. Sarah and I went to the village and called on Lina's mother, also at the two Mrs. Pughs, at Douglass's and Montagues. Maria's mother said she should like to have her take lessons, but did

not speak very decidedly about it. Mrs. H. Pagh says they are somewhat bothered in money affairs now. Mr Pugh, you know is just starting business on his own account and many of his customers ar slow to pay. If it were not for that she thought she would like to have her daughter learn. She thought T? Morgan's little boy would take lessons. His parents are very anxious for him to take lessons on the melodian. He now plays well on the violin, and has musical talent. Neither Mr. Douglass or Mr. Montague's people appeared to think that their girls would take lessons. Isabel says their teacher, Mr. Jenkyn, intends to have a piano in his school next term, which opens next Meonday. A lady from Boonville, I believe is to give lessons on it She has been trying sometime to get a class. Lina's

mother says the feel the pressure of the times very much. Their property is City property. Lina is quite occupied with attending school, knitting for soldiers & c. If it were otherwise she would like much to have Lina take lessons. We think Rush would certainly take lessons, but have not seen her since Mother wrote. We think She and Maria (if she takes lessons) would like quite as well, and perhaps prefer to take lessons on the Melodian. Mrs. Pugh promised to speak to Mrs. Morgan and also to R. Roberts people about Mary. The district school is very flourishing now, and takes the children's time, still we think of you once got started with a few. you might soon have more. We spoke to Ellen Owen. She did not know but thought you might succeed
Maria Edward is not at home

Feb. 8 1876
What has become of Uncle Eddie & Aunt Male have they got snowed in? Are you all well? Have Uncle E & Aunt M been at your house yet We expected them last week and are and shall expect them until they come. Lovingly F. E. L. 
Are all well here We haven't found Aunt Annas pictures yet F. E. L.

Remsen April 1880
Dear Aunt Anna
Your very welcome letter of April 13 was recieved promptly. Frankie was very much delighted to recieve it, the same as my self. I have been to Uncle Lewis' making a dress for Aunt Jame last week. They are all well there. I have been at several places near home sewing, and have been to Utica to. We are busy house cleaning these days we want to get through before Louisa commences her school. She is going to teach as the coverd brigge school. Her school opens the first Monday in May.

Tell John Eddie that I scarcily think Frankie will attend school this Summer, but she teaches school in Mother's bedroom and talks about her schoolars tells what caprice they have been doing during the day. She has such queer names for her scholars that a stranger would almost believe her. What Frank says she wants from New York is a present. She wots me to tell, that Aunt Laura gave her two dresses, and I will send you a sample of cashmere we have in the house, do you think it would make a pretty dress for her trimed with lace of the same shade and blue ribon bows. She went to Prospect to-day with Uncle John and Aunt Bessy to see little Bola Haskins before she goes away. Dr. Haskins is going to Colorado. they start Monday. I believe

I told in my last letter that John Roberts is going to Sioux City. Iowa I was sorry to here that Aunt Sarah has been sick I hope she is better before this time. How does Aunt Jennie stand it. I suppose she is having a good time. Of course Aunt Mary is well for Doctors have no rights to be sick at all. We will let you know when as soon as the weather gets warm here. it is quite cold yet. But the roads are pretty good now The new minister will preach for the first time at Remsen to morrow his name is Smith he is quite a young man about 22 years, I think. Proff. Gardner of Whitstown is dead funeral to be Monday Josie Hughes is coming to make us a visit next vacation

Frankie wants you to bring little Grace Jones home you with you, so she can have her to play with her, Frank will love to have more practice before she can write a letter But I am quite certain that she will come up to this very soon. Please write soon again and tell the rest to write. We all unite in sending our love to you all.
I remain as ever your friend
and neice J. E. Everett
Oh, yes Frank's dog is mane is Topsy her doll is mane is Goldie blue eyes.

Turin Sept 15th 1880
Dear Sisters
It is now after nine Edward has not come home from the store yet, he has been over the river to-day as usual. We went up to see about his lumber last Sat. they say they can't saw unless it rains I was glad to see the rain come Sun. Lumber has come up and if he could get it out in two or three weeks he could

make about $300 on it and he could tell better what he would do this coming winter. I reed a postal from Mary this Wed. noon asking if he could be at the meeting in R_ Wed- to day I have seen nothing of you & Anna yet arnt you coming back? & if that cousin comes she can come up here. Carroll & Charlie go to school and it is rather lonely for me though I keep busy. That pattern I spoke of was that unclear I made my lace on I don't know as I shall make

another now I did think I would make one for Mother Mrs. Karliskint was here yester washed & partly ironed & done some sweeping E has just come & brought some grapes you see what you miss by not being here Mon morn. I did not finnish this as I am not very smart Carroll or Charlie will stay home with me to day. Arent you all comeing up here before long I do wish you could come & stay till you go to New York write us when you will be

I have not seen Aunt Katie to speak to her yet I don't think she has been out much of late several have said that when you come back they are going to call on you, I was down to Mrs Evans last week she was well Mrs W is getting along nicely. Hope to hear from you soon come if you can with much love from each of us to you all how is the baby? Is Lewis better? Mate
H. left her silver paper shall I send it?

Turin Feb 2nd/880
Dear Sisters

 It is Sat. morn. and I thought I would drop you a few lines. I thought E_ had written before now. He has been very busy, packing up T.J. old goods. Charlie has rented the store for 8 years taking possession yesterday. T.J. has gone to Albany yes- I went with E. down to Cousin Emma Johnson stayed all day I heve not been very well the fore part of the week am better now. Carroll is sick found him feverish last night

he has some fever this morning. Last Sat I asked Dr Johnson for his bill he brought it to me Wednesday & to my surprise it was only $30.30 for about four months treatment some weeks coming 2 or 3 times We thought it would be about $80. Edward said about apples if it would not be to much trouble & work for you a barrell of apples would be very acceptable Edward was over to see about his lumber. The man said if it continued to rain he would get it out in two weeks. I was in hopes it would continue to rain

I hope week after next you & Anna will be here come if you can. George Prichard sleeps here nights as as they have no room over to A.W. for him Ed. told him he might come for a week till he could get another place it has been a week Today Mrs. K- comes once in two weeks & washes & irons for us we get along nicely. I only weigh 123 now, E is very well Charlie is my right hand man. Do you hear from John E.?

Your slips are doing nicely Jimmie brought us a bag of apples last night- they were very acceptable apples seem to be plenty they are from 25 & 30 up to unclear cents a bushul. You see we have not gone to Kansas I have felt all of the time that if it was best for us to go the lumber would get ready to start off. Hope to from you soon We could tell the differences in writing 
Love from each of us to you all
from
E. &. M-

New York Dec 30/81
Dear Home Folkes:
The little reminder was welcome today. I was pleased to hear that S. is improving. I hope she will eat ever so much & gain strength next week. We have had a very pleasant day. Shall be anxious to know how the blinds look. Are they to be primed with green or some other. Hope the paint will not be offensive. Met Mrs. Thomas 38th St. in the cars yesterday. She enquired very kindly & sends love

I have been rather lazy today or should have written earlier in the day. The dining room up stairs is ever so much pleasanter there as we had it before & I have a very quiet time all to myself. Shall make more progress with my studies, but I feel lost somewhat. Went up stairs this afternoon & laid on Mrs. Van Benn's bed. It seemed quite nice & restful. Has S. sat up any more since I left. & how much does she eat. & Anna you may take this same question to yourself! Much Much love, Mollie

Dear Auntie
I thought I would write you a letter. papa killed a gopher yestardy. I found 23 badger holes and one praiarie dogs. I went to Church last sunday. One of the Indians came to sell wood. I saw two praiarie wolves yestarday. I saw a flock of wild geese and praiarie chickens. I went with papa to Draw hay yestarday. how do you feel. We are living with Uncle Wills folks now. We got a letter from Aunt Jennie since we came here.
good bye,
Lewis.

Buffalo Center Apr. 1st 1890
Dear Aunt Anna.
I have only time to write just a word this time. Will is going to the post Office and I will send just a word to let you know that we are alive and well. We are sowing wheat and consequently are quite busy The weather is quite pleasant but it is too cold for vegetation to start yet. The country about here is far from being level and still farther from being like the country back there look from your house to Capel Uchaf and imaging not a tree stump or stone and you will have an idea of some of the prarie about here The claim I have taken is much more level than that. Hoping to hear from you soon, I am your nephew R.H. Everett

Sprague, Wash. 
Sept. 13, 1890
Dear Aunt Anna:
I suppose you are having a visit just now from Holden, Hattie & Eva. Wish we lived a little nearer, so we could be there too. I often think of the pleasant weeks I spent there last summer. It hardly seems possible that we can be so far away now. I have been meaning to write you ever since we came. Am sorry we could not have had that visit before we left Phoenix. We find things here very different from those in the
Did Hattie receive the letter I wrote her, directed to Petoskey? We have received no Independents from the N.Y. office as yet.

East, with some things favorable and others not so pleasant. We have plenty of fruit out here, of the best kind, peaches, pears, plums, apples, grapes, &c. &c. The prices are about the same this season as in the East, for fruit, especially peaches, has not been so abundant as usual. Apples, however are much higher, being 5 cts. a pound, the same as pears, peaches being 10 cts. We bought splendid large yellow peaches at $1.00 a box and put up 8 or 10 quarts, about the same of pears, and today I got a box of prunes, for canning at the same price. These resemble blue plums, but are larger & sweeter. They are very nice to eat in the hand. Most of the fruit comes from the Snake river, some from Oregon.

We like the climate here so far, except the dust. The air is fresh and bracing, and the nights always cool. Think my health has improved somewhat since coming.
Azia was very homesick at first, but has got more acquainted and used to it now. The baby has been cutting his double teeth this summer, and has not been very well. His head seems to trouble him, and we have to be careful of him, for fear he will have more fits. This morning he sat for his picture, which we hope will be good. He has not had any taken since the time I was at your house. We are hoping to go to Spokane Falls tomorrow for a week's visit, if Clarence is well enough. Last night he frightened us by crying and being

feverish, so that it was quite late before he got to sleep. We give him bromide and chloral for his nervousness. There is no homeopathic physician here, for which we are sorry. He does not walk alone yet, or talk, altho he is nearly 20 months old. We have a small parsonage here, next to the church, supplied with city water, and the church is lighted with electricity. We have a fine choir, and good S. school. There are a good many Welsh people around here, and some in the church. Mr. Griffiths, the Baptist minister of Utica, was here a short time ago. He is editor of a Welsh magazine. We hope you are all well and prospering. Hope you will write us soon. With love to all including the visitors. J. H. Butler.

Olpe, Kas. Feb. 19/91.
Dear Aunt Anna, -
I am sending you to-day photos of Carroll and Ray. Carroll's picture was taken last June and Ray's the middle of January. It is very quiet in the store to-day, as it has been raining all day. Yesterday was very cold and it snowed all day. More snow than we have had in all winter. I suppose you know that Kansas is subject to most extreme changes, last Monday for instance; early in the morning it was so warm that it was uncomfortable to stay in the house without the windows or doors open, and in the

afternoon it was so cold that it was most impossible to ride faceing the wind. Carroll hasn't been home from school since the holidays. To-morrow will be the most eventful and looked forward to with the most interest by all of the college students of Kansas, of all the college year. It being the Annual Inter-collegiate Oratorical contest of Kansas. This year it will be held in the Whitley opera house, of Emporia under the management of the State Normal. Five colleges, the State Normal of Emporia and the State University of Lawrence will be represented. The colleges which will be represented are situated at the following places; Emporia (Presbyterian), Topeka

(Washburn, a Congregational institution), Baldwin Cy. (Methodist) Ottawa and Salina. The Mendelssohn Quartette of the Emporia College in which Carroll sings 2nd Bass, will sing at the contest. The admission is seventy five cents, and there was such a demand for tickets that all were sold before Tuesday. I was lucky enough to get one. Carroll sings in the choir of the First Presbyterian church of Emporia and gets one dollar a Sunday. Today is Eddies seventh birthday, he weighs nearly as much as Robbie and learns fast in school. Harry has just got over a siege of pneumonia. I have not been going to school at all this winter, but have been kept pretty buisy in the store. Trade has

been much better this winter than last, about fifty percent.
It is not because the so-called Peoples party or farmers alliance party has got in power but if they were not in power in this state buisiness would be a great deal better for the reason that farmers that have mortgages coming due cannot get them reviewed, nor can they borrow any money, because money loaners are afraid of what the Alliance legislature will do.
Well, as I am nearing the bottom of this page I will have to close
With love from all I'll bid adieu.
Your Nephew
Chas. H. Everett

Alder Creek Dec. 27, 1891
Dear Cousins; -
I wrote in my last letter that I would write again in a week, but after sending it I came to the conclusion that it would take you a week to read it, if indeed, you would succeed at the end of that time, then I thought you would need some time to recruit after the punishment I had inflicted on you. And I didn't feel at all flattered as I suspected I would, over the idea that you would be looking forward to the nesct issue from the pen, or rather pencil

of Mr. Everett!!! but felt ashamed to think I had sent such a horrid scribble, but my escuse was that I was short of paper and I wanted to send all news I could for two cents, but I will try to do better this time. I am commencing a new pad and if this isn't enough for me we have another so I feel quite independent as far as paper goes.
How have you been getting along. I think it is time you wrote to let us know "somethin anyow"
We have our ups and down's. about for weeks ago Uncle and Auntie had a sick time. Auntie still feels from it. it was Rheumatism in her neck and shoulder, until

she would not move and now it is my turn. I took a hard cold, or had the "grippe" week before last Wednesday and have barked ever since. at first I was so hoarse I couldn't speak and coughed very hard. Aunt Annie put flax seed poultices on my chest and it did me so much good. I think I would of had Pneumonia only they worked over me so faithfully. night before last I coughed for about an hour and a half without stopping and had to sit up in bed all night and last night too. Just as soon as I would lie down I would cough, so in order to sleep I had to sit up with half a dozen

4 
pillows to my back and all the remedies we could think of on a table by my bedside. well I think I have written enough about myself, but you know it is a good subject, and I don't know when to stop when I do get hold of a subject that is "throughly good."
It is Sunday evening and we are alone, it has been snowing all day and we are very glad to see it after so much mud. it rained every day last week, from Tuesday about 10 oclock in the morning until Saturday night, when the wind changed, went to the north and this morning it was snowing. 
Mrs. William H. Jones had a sale, sold some

5
furniture all the stock and a lot of stuff that usually collects around a farm. and has moved to Remsen. She is going to keep house for William Thomas until Spring, provide for herself and have fire, light and house for cooking and washing for him. I saw Aunt Jane at Mrs. Jone's auction. she looked well and said she was escpecting Clara home that night to stay for a week, Thanksgiving week. We have not heard from there since.
We have not heard a word from Father since I was with you in Remsen although I have written twice if we do not hear soon I will write again. John was here last month. wished to be remembered to

6
you when I wrote. he is still in Stratford.
Now I will go back to the time we closed up the house. Monday Morning I wanted to go up to the house to begin to pack things in order. Aunt J. was washing but I saw that she did not want me to go alone. she wanted me to wait until she finished washing and she and Frank would go with me and take the horses, so I helped her, and we had "ta back," about 1/2 past 9 and 10 oclock we went to the old home. the first thing I did was to make fire then collect all the letters I could find put them in the bosc (Evan Roberts had given me) and I got Frank to nail it up. Aunt J. began to sweep

Miss Anna L. Everett
c/o Mrs. Lizzie Sands
West North St
Hillsdale
Michigan
Opposite College

Alder Creek March 27th/92 
Dear Cousins; -

Your letter of  Feb 2 still unanswered and  it is a shame, when I prom- ised to write so often to  tell all the news, "but never  mind better luck next time".  I think when I left off last  time I left Aunt Jane sweeping up stairs, well, she hasn't been sweeping  all this time for it only  took her a few minutes and I folded and put away some things that  had been left, Cousin Marys ulster I put on the fence  and took the carpet  beater to it then put it  up with the tobacco, we found the handle of one of your Fathers and Mothers silver spoons that was broken

by the side of Cousin Anna's bed and we put it in  the middle small drawer of the Bureau in the alcove.  I think everything was  fixed very snug and nice.  I hope you are both well, and enjoy living opposite  the College I am sure it must be very nice to see  all the young people going  back and forth. I wish I could just drop in to  see you, I don't suppose  you have any snow there, but we have had plenty here  for you and us too, we have had very hard storms this month.  I hope your brother John got over his sickness and was able to return  home soon after Cousin M  had to leave him, how are  his eyes? Is J.E. in  Harper and Anthony now

3

when he wrote he did not know whether he would be there or not and I did not write, right  away so now I don't  know where to write to I am ashamed of myself  for not thanking him for his photo. I received a letter from my Sister Lizzie in the Winter she had 3 children 2 boys and 1 girl and in Feb she had another boy so that makes 4 children. Uncle John's family were all well, and were doing well they were all in business boys and girls. Uncle Lewis and Aunt Mary were well, now I have  told all the news that will  interest you. Do you think you  will come to New York this Spring or stay in the West

4

I am going to tell you  a big secret I know you  wont tell any one, Maggie Humphreys is going to be married to Prior Kent next month or the first of May and she wants me to go with her to Utica to buy her dress and some other things, she wants me to make her dress, but I will  not cut and fit it, she must get some one to do  that and I will finish it  for her I am going to make over 2 dresses, one black and one blue, and make three calico dresses, so I will be busy for a while. I have been sick nearly  all Winter but I am better now  Auntie has had several sick spells too, but we are all  pretty well now, hoping to  hear from you soon, love from all to you both. 

Lovingly Mary Everett

send my love to J.E. when  you write to him, and  please let me know where  he is now, write soon  and tell us all the news  my love to little Anna. Lizzie and May are  playing a duet, and I  am trying to do two things  at once, write and listen  to them, so don't do well  at either. Aunt Annie  sends love to both of you. bushels of love from  all M Everett

Mary G or 6 or C

 5

P.S. J.H. was here the first of last month. he is still in Stratford, he was asking for you, how you were and if the climate agreed with you. Were you going to stay longer than Spring. that he would never forget his visit at the old home as he calls it.
We have not seen Aunt Jane for some time so do not know how they are. Her Humphreys moved the first of this month to a farm between Remsen and Prospect owned by John Edwards (dead) or I should of said owned by J. Edwards widow perhaps you know where it is.

Actual date is 1893
Holland Patent N.J.
Feb. 6. 1892
Dear Aunt Anna
Your very welcome
letter I received this morning, and
were very glad to hear from you,
but were very sorry to hear that
father Everett was sick, hope that 
you have heard more encouraging 
news before this time. are very glad
that John Eddie was situated so
that he could go to see his father
as he must be very lonely there,
are very much olige to you for
informing me of his sickness
will be very thankful to you for
letting me know how he is as often
as you hear. For I will be anscious
to hear. I received a letter from

Frankie last Saturday saying that she had received a letter from you that her grampa Everett was sick but I did not know how sick he was. Frankie had always cherish the hope that she could see her Grandpa Everett and I hope that she may yet; she always seem to have a great love for him. so much more than anyone would expect a child to have for a person that she had never seen; She has always seem to feel so mornfully and said to think of her father that she had never seen him and how she had missed a fathers' love, care, and affections. probably that might be the cause of her affection to her Grampa. feeling that he is her father's father
I am so happy to think that Frankie is getting along so well, and has been so fortunate as to have such a good Uncle as Dr. Jones. her life

is so different to what it would be if she were to live here with us. There was such a change in her that when she came here last Summer I did not know her myself when I went to meet her at the Depot she has had one misfortune and that is; to have Timothy get married he use to clothe her and pay for her music ( she is a fine Piano player) and now Timothy's wife will not allow him to give her anything, so I try and clothe her myself the best I can, and she needs to be well dressed. well, so as not to be different from the rest of the girls, and they are all wealthy peoples children, so I hope that if she has her health she will get along all right. my health is improving but am not able to do but very little

yet. I have been very sick I had both plurisy & pneumonia. so you see I was double sick. Father has been very sick too, he has not been out of the house for over 4 months but we hope that the warm weather will help him. the rest of us are well and all wish to be remembered very kindly to you and Aunt Mary. And also John Eddie when you write to tell him that we all wish to be remembered to him and bride & wish them both a long and happy life
Hoping to hear from you very soon
I am as ever your affectionate neice: Esther Everett

Remsen N.Y.
July 20, 1893.
Dear Aunt Anna,
I am staying at Grandma's now, I came here two weeks ago tomorrow. Papa is not here but is coming.
Uncle Will and Erving was here a week ago, and Erving dressed up like a cook, and pretended he was Bridget, and he acted like one too.
You have never written to me, now I expect a letter for me from you. 
I have the Shingles on my left side, and Aunt Mary told me that you have had them.

I would of liked you to come with Aunt Mary, because I want to see you very much.
I expect you would like to see Marion, she is a very nice and pretty baby, she can say Papa and Mama, and she says nana, and she means grandma, she also says Jeff. Marion takes hold of a chair and pushes it along, walking, she is now calling "Nana", so cute.
Frankie is here now I presume you know.
Frank put the swing up, and I enjoy myself very much a swinging. 
I go on the hay loads most every day, and am getting very fat.
In case of Aunt Mary. Your loving neice
Bertha.

1.
Utica, N.Y. May 24, 1893.
My dear cousin Annie,
My conscience has been very troublesome for some time past. It has bothered and bothered me, and finally has stirred me up to do something that I should have done long ago. I wouldn't blame you, my dear, if you had thought very hard things about me during the weeks - rather months that have passed, and had vowed never again to write to so uncousinly a cousin. But, dear chum, I know that

3
to have one of us play on the piano while he "sings". I suppose the public would hardly consider the song first-class; but little Albert and his relatives think it just beautiful. I wish you could see the little red-cheeked, blue-eyed chubby boy, I am sure that you would fall in love with him as I have done. His papa is well, but Hattie's health, I am sorry to say, is very poor. She took a hard cold last summer, and in the fall, when she came to Utica to visit, was so much worse that the Dr. advised her not to return to Prospect. Since that time, she, Albert, and baby,

have been staying at her mother's in this city. In spite of the change and the care of a good physician, Hattie has steadily failed during the winter, and now, Albert tells us, the doctor thinks it hardly probably that she will recover. She is not confined to her bed all the time, but has her bad days and her good ones. Perhaps the warm weather will do her good, and she will get better this summer. I do hope that this may be, and that things are not so bad as the doctor thinks, for it does seem hard to think that this little

family must be separated so soon; they are so happy together. If they knew that I were writing to you to-day, I am sure they would send their love to both of you. I generally read your letters to brother Albert, and he enjoys them very much, as do the rest of us - Yes, believe me, Annie, I enjoy and appreciate them - although I am so long in answering them - ungrateful girl that I am - "just like the Ev" - O, excuse me! I was almost forgetting that you are one of that dreadful tribe. We were especially interested in one part

you are altogether too good to have done either of these things. If it were Mary, now, that Mary that used to beat me so badly, I should hardly dare hope for mercy; but you - why you would forgive your "little Clara" "until seventy times seven" if necessary, wouldn't you? Taking this for granted, I shall not spend the time in making excuses for my last transgression - of which, by the way, I do not know the exact number - but shall proceed directly to business.
First of all, I must tell you some very good news; something

that you will be glad to hear, I know. I have another little nephew, a little New Yorker, this time. The young man arrived at about eight o'clock A.M. Palm Sunday, and when last heard from was doing very nicely. Ella is very happy over the event, and James is exceedingly proud of his son, George Palmer Sanford, - for as the dear boy was named by his fond papa even before Easter. We rejoice in their good fortune, and do hope that this little one will be spared, it will be such a comfort to them. Ella writes that she thinks of visiting

of your last letter, i.e. that concerning the marriage. We were not altogether surprised to hear that cousin Eddie was married, as he was of a marriageable age, and we had no idea that he would be content to live in "single blessedness" all his life; but we were rather taken by alarm when we found that he had a whole family all at once. My! he didn't want much, did he? Tell him, when you write, that I think he was just horrid to get married without sending a fellow an invitation, or cake, or anything. and, when my turn comes, I am going to pay

I generally read your letters to brother Albert, and he enjoys them very much, as do the rest of us - Yes, believe me, Annie, I enjoy and appreciate them - although I am so long in answering them - ungrateful girl that I am - "just like the Ev" - O, excuse me! I was almost forgetting that you are one of that dreadful tube. We were especially interested in one part

us as usual this summer; that is, if baby keeps well, and is strong enough to take the journey. They will probably come in June and remain until Sept. We wish it were so that you and Mary could be here to have a visit with Ella, and get acquainted with Master George. My other little nephew is now a big boy almost two years old - so pretty, so bright, so affectionate, we all love him. He loves us, too, and thinks grandpa and grandma Jones are just about right. He is very observing for so young a child, and talks a great deal. He likes

3.
him up for it. I wont let him know a thing about it until it is all over with - so there now! You may tell him, however, that I wish him much joy in his married life - we all do - and hope that he has a good wife who will be a help to him in his work. Our best wishes to him and his little family. You ask in your letter about brother Owen. He has been a very busy boy since he left school. After graduating in June, he decided that he would not go to college - this year, at least; and as soon as possible began to look around for a place to work. Through

one of his friends, he heard of a position as assistant book-keeper and clerk at a hardware and plumbing establishment on Genesee H. Although this was not just to his liking, he thought best to accept it until something better should turn up. He commenced work the first part of Sept. and continued until the early part of March - when he was offered a position as city editor of the Rome Republication, a weekly paper. He undertook the job, but found that it was too difficult for him, it required a person of more

experience in that line, than he had had; so, after a few weeks, he gave it up and came home. The day after he returned, his former Employer sent to the house to ask him to resume his old position. This he did, and continued in it until a month ago, when he accepted a place as reporter on the Utica Morning Herald - which he now holds. He has done nicely so far, and likes the work very well. His paper, Our Delight; he discontinued last summer before he secured his first position. He thought best to do so, as the Expense connected with it; which

he himself paid, amounted to quite a sum each month, and he felt that the paper was not benefitting him financially. Since then, he has been rather sorry that he was not a little more patient, and did not give it a longer trial, as he has reason to believe that it could have been a success had he done so
Well, Experience is the best teacher he will know better what to do the next time he starts a paper of his own. As Our Delight did not continue through the twelve months, in order to deal fairly with his subscribers, he paid the Editor of the Public School Bulletin for supplying them with that

4
paper for the remainder of the year. I think that it was a very good substitute, dont you? My pupil resumed her lessons in Sept. and continued until last month; not regularly, however, as she is not in very good health, and was often unable to take the three lessons a week agreed upon. Last month she took a vacation and, a few days ago, her mother came to the house to ask me to extend it; and to make arrangements for next fall. The latter I thought best not to do; for, although I am very fond of Mabel and enjoyed teaching her, I did not feel justified in continuing another year

as I have this - Such intermittent work is hardly profitable to either pupil or teacher. You know. So I have given her up. By this mail, I send you copies of "Womankind" and the "American Farmer and Farm News", papers published by the same company as you will see, in which I have a department for the little folks. It was started about six months ago, and the boys and girls seem to like it very well. Perhaps Howard and his little sister would like to contribute a letter. They may write about anything they choose. I am sure my "nephews"

and "nieces" would be delighted to hear about those wonderful ducks that Howard tells of in his composition. I met your friend Mrs Morgan yesterday, and told her I was writing to you. She said to give her love to you both, and to tell Mary that she would surely write her a letter. We were glad to hear that you and Mary had so pleasant a visit at Chicago. It must have done you good. I am glad, dear Annie, that the weather behaved itself, and was just your kind. It was very accommodating, wasn't it? How is your health now? does Michigan

agree with you as well as ever? I wish that you would get tired of it and travel this way again. We would love to have you "bother" us some more. If you come, I promise you, I won't ask you to read your morning chapter out of the Welsh Bible, or maltreat you in any other way. I may plague Mary a little, but you won't mind that much, will you? We have had a great deal of warm weather here, this spring. It has been rainy some days, of course, we expect that this part of the year; but there have been many fine days, too. To-day is one of them. Yesterday was hot and oppressive, but a heavy thunder shower, late

5
in the afternoon, cooled the air and made it delightful. It is just lovely to-day. Our health has been quite good the past winter, with the exception of colds. Mama took a cold and had a hard time of it for a few weeks. That old "grippe" has bothered her every year since she had it and it couldn't, of course, pass her by this time. But she has been better than usual this winter, I think. Papa has been very well until this week. Sunday he took cold and was sick abed Monday and Tuesday. Today he is somewhat better. The rest of us are very well. Now, dear

chum, I would like to hear from you very soon; but don't dare ask it, because - you know why. Please do not keep me waiting as long as I have kept you - I beg of you - If you do, I shall not get a reply to this until next November - Just think of it! Have compassion on me, do. We all send love to both. Emma says that she sends a wee bit of love to her chum and will write to her as soon as she can get a good sharp point on her pencil. I send lots and lots of love to you, and hope you can read this long letter from your
"Little Clara."
Clara Lewis Jones.
56 South St.

Home Oct 15, 1898

Dear sister & all,

    Please excuse pencil as my ink has given out. I fear that I have been neglecting of late and do not know where I left off in my diary but will begin with  Saturday P. M. Went to church meeting and there Laura told me that Jennie Prince wanted to see me at her house at 4 P.M. Went down and after a while the bonnet came. It is said to be pretty and becoming. Cost for frame 25 cts., Making 50 cts- Had previously left my broadcloth (from the cloak) at Ms. Wms. and was to have been at her house Sat. A.M. but failed to go down was getting my ribbons ready &c. Went in there in the evening and she thought she could make of

it and appointed Monday P.M. for me to come down. Staid with Laura that night. Sunday went with Ellen Davies from church and after dinner went to Peniel where they had prayer meeting. Miriam Jones took possession of me as I came from church and took me home with her. She had a good many questions to ask about our Saratoga  friends &c and told me that she and Mr. Jones, and Minnie and Augustina? I think spent one winter at Jacksonville Florida, which she enjoyed very much indeed, - In course of conversation we talked about tomatoes as they had a great many ripening in the windows. She  said there were a good many more  on the vines and they had brought in all they wanted. So she offered them to me if I would

come for them which I did Monday P.M, There was quite a nice lot, several quarts. Gave Sarah some & brought the rest home & they are ripening in the windows. I have been well supplied this summer, Jane has given me some several times & these are such a treat. Mrs. Wms. cut & made without lining  my cape Monday afternoon and it cost me but 50 cts for the making. It is very pretty & nice as it is now & I can line it later on. The edge like yours, Derby collar. It is not so full as some but looks nice. Staid at Laura's Monday night. Did not go to church as I had some sewing. Went to hear the last sermon Tuesday morning, Henry Reed, son of Gwilyn Hiraethag. By the way I was introduced to him by cousin Robert Everett who is well acquainted with him

and with Mr. Williams "Hwfa Mon." Mr. Hwfa Mon preached in the afternoon & evening. His sermons are from one and a half to two hours long & interesting. So all gave way to him & there was but one seminar at each of these services. I took dinner with Mrs. Squrie Lewis & tea at Robt Hughes Cousin Robt was with me at the latter place. He came up with me that evening & staid at Lauras. I came up in the morning Wednesday Seth Williams was buried after an illness of but a week (pneumonia) Ann, (his widow now) has been  quite sick with heart trouble & this comes very hard for her. Cousin Mary has been with them & stayed after the funeral. Cousin Robert came back from the funeral to help me and will help me back. Yesterday & today have

2
been beautiful days, sunny & warm. Robt has fixed the front stoop which was sagging badly & put a new threshold at the back door. It was in a bad state you know, but is very nice now. I found an old table leaf in the shed, probably a mate to one that had been used before & it has done very nicely. I did not think we could make so good a job of it. I lately found that the horse barn roof was leaking quite a little and we decided to patch it. They say that cheap shingles are good enough for patching. I found some cedar shingles at Robt Griffith's for $2.00 for a thousand. I got five hundred two bundles & yesterday P.M. & little while this morning Frank was up to put them on. I went inside & with a long stick pointed out to him where the light came

through. He said it was a help to him to have me inside. He put on all the shingles & we think it is a good job. Frank came up yesterday morning to see how many shingles were wanted & after he left I thought it would be just the chance to get up some boxes for packing so I whipped down the village in a jiffy, got some boxes which he brought up & tomorrow Robt & I are going to work at it. I have been putting together things all summer. Do not know just how much bedding to bring but will judge as well as I can. I found those feather tips with the things that I had put together to go. Hardly know whether it is best to take them now as I have my similar bonnet made and

you have yours. I sold the hymn books at 40 cts & they have promised to put the matter before the church after the meetings are over. They have been to great expense to fit up their church  & hardly dared to speak to the people about it now before promised subscriptions were paid. Have ceiled  with boards like ours above and under the galery & papered the walls. also have a new chandelier & done some painting. They said they needed the books badly enough & thought they would want some after a while. Perhaps I had better leave some with Mariann or some one.

I am sitting on your couch, end towards the parlor. Birds are singing and branches waving without. The curtain in front hall is fluttering and I hear little crackling noises in the  pantry from the paper on shelves; as they are moved by the breeze. It is six minutes past two P.M. I have had my lunch and a nap and now will indulge in a little chat with you. This morning after looking for the third or fourth time, for that "Macaulay,
Frankie is looking quite thin weighs 110 lbs. Has weighed 130., 120 last summer. I think she studies too hard. She has read Ceaser,  Cicero, and three books in Virgil and now wants to read Livy while out of school. afterreading Livy she will be ready for the Sophmore class. jumping the Freshman class. She wanted to go home and mage arrangement to read Livy with some one in the Patent during this vacation. Thanks to her Aunt Louise's & continue Livy during the year. — Clara has quite a notion of going to Mt Holyoke. Same time when she cannot this year, as she must earn first. Maggie weighs 151 lbs! and looks noble they say

Vols 1 &2, in vain,  it occurred to me that possibly it might be with my books that came from N.G., and have been boxed up so long. I borrowed a few books once after mother’s death. Had offered the two boxes a few days ago, finding them all night. Well, to my great pleasure, there was the missing book all right. Have put it with the others to go to Merrill. Have I mentioned that E’s mother Bible is here, containing the family record! It was on the table in the parlor. Has at sometime suffered a little from dampness. Some of the leaves somewhat discolored, otherwise all right, and is in study with the
Bertha is most well of her shingles. I was her doctor as the have? Homeopathy at home. Aconite set the baby right I wanted Jane to counsult Dr. S. as he is her physician and understands her. She has an attack like this every year she says just at this time in haying.

others. I wish you could be here for a day.  It is warmer than it was the first of the week,  Sunday night near Bethel there was quite a frost whitening the corn and farther North, potatoes were injured. Called at Rev. E. Davies last evening & he gave me this report. He had taken a severe cold. Sat. was very warm & he had put on the  thinest clothing that he had before going to Bethel. It turned cold and he suffered all day Sunday. Had no overcoat even. Moral,  when ministers go from here to their appointments it would be  wise to go prepared for changes in the weather. I met Elizabeth Roberts (Morris) 
Most lovingly with a share for all, Mary. 
Will write to Howard and Zaidee next time but want to send this on account of the Aconite.

(2.)
up a box of flowers to send you when I came home, but failed to do so. (forgive me) I found a little Alegany vine also. There was no crop raised in the garden this year. Lizrie said they raised peas here last year and Mr. Evan's chickens got them most all. So they felt discouraged. The grape vine looks very nicely, with quite a lot of grapes. You would be surprised to see the hop vine. Hugh has three tall poles put up and the strong vines reach the top. Susie said they had a nice lot of hops from them last year 
I got the roots, perhaps you remember, from Mrs. P. G. Jones' near cabin. O, I have not told you that one day soon after I came home Mrs. Jones called me when I was down to Jane's, and left for me (with Hugh) a bowl of her lovely butter. I do so wish I could share with you, it is not half gone yet I bring up bread and put or my butter here. Was she not kind?

The friends all inquire so much about you and send messages of love.  At David's funeral yesterday I saw Rosellen Mitchel & Ellen Evans.  They had many inquiries to make about you both and urged me much to call.  Rosellen said that her father was very badly off.  Jane had told me that his mind is in a very bad state, that Rosellen had told her.  I must try and call there.  I had quite a little visit with Mrs. Griffith Floyd.  walked with her from the house to the church.  She said that Ruth & Jasmine Ellis were at home now, and Maria of course as housekeeper.  Annie in N.Y. nursing.  She is but little lame. Was very sick last winter with the grip but is now well.  Mrs. G. visited the girls not long since at Whitesboro.  She lives alone in her home.  one of Ruth's children coming to stay with he nights Saw also at the funeral, Mrs. Henry Parry.  She lives alone also.  Gwen & John D. are looking well this summer.  The neighbors here take their milk to Sixty Thos. Evans carrying it.  So John D. has to take his own & they retire very early and rise early enough for him to get back from the factory before Six.  So Laura told me.  Had quite a visit also with Jo. Roberts wife She is looking quite thin & pale was very 
I have written to cousin M. L. about the medicine

too cold. so we look Sarah's box down there & read some of the poetry in which all were much interested. I brought the box back next day. will take it back when I go. shall I not.?-- Jennie Griffith was engaged to Wm. Thomas, and mourns his death very much.--I have not found that Vol on psick? yet. Looked cursorally over my books, but did not see it but will search again. Do you not think this letter a little better than the B. Herald. Pretty full of gossip I think.-- Jane has been quite sick for a few days, Had Cholera Morbus, Wednesday morning. went to see Dr. Swarthout who ordered her to bed. She is much better, but was not up when I left this morning.-- Frankie returned here in a couple of days. She does not expect to attend school the next year as her uncle has been to much expense moving &c this year (1st page)

cordial. You will think that I visited a great deal of the funeral. Well I was early, and they delayed a good deal. There were about as many people outside as in the house, and a good deal of the time I was on the piazza. Mary Ann Lloyd is looking very well. She is at Joseph Francis'. Laura was up to the funeral. at the house walked both ways. Had to take it slowly of course. She is looking some better. John G. Jones comes to church now. Two of Richd Prichard's girls from below here are in the class. Willie R. Williams is growing to be quite a young man. He has a class of small boys. Several from a Williams family from

below here. One of them is Secretary. Mr. George of Rome gave us an excellent sermon last Sabbath. Text Isa. 43:21. His wife came with him. There seems to be a good deal of life in the church. Wm. H. Williams has been chosen Deacon since Wm. Thomas' death; and seems to be a good one. Wm. J. Price is not looking well. Says he is better than he has been looks thin and yellow. Gwen says he works too hard. Mrs. H. Thomas is looking well. They have a livery every Sunday morning come to the church. Mrs. Wm. Lewis Mrs. Hugh.
