John D. & Gwen came one Sunday in their own conveyance as usual Have not seen Mrs. Robt Jones yet. Saw Abbie once at Post Office Ellen Davies looks pretty well but is lonely.

Thos. Owen of Uticca is to reach next Sabbath. I have not told you that in one of the heavy storms this spring a large branch blew down onto the garden from the maple tree farthest west and on North row I must have it sawed off the place smoothed and painted. Jane says that Frank will do it after haying. They have finished there but Frank has gone to help Mr. McArthur. Every one is busy in the haying. Some are nearly through "O, they busy month of haying." There is a charm in it and "a sweetness in the air." Jane came up with me last Sabbath afternoon and we had quite a visit here, and read some of Sarah's verses. It was too cold for Bertha to come, with her shingles, Baby was a little under the weather also her mother & Clara had to stay as her mother came We had planned to come all of us & visit in front yard but it was

there, also Mrs. Griffith widow of Rev J.R.G. of Floyd. who came to attend D Price's funeral. There was a large funeral (at the house) Rev E. Davies preached. I did not hear the text but finally got near enough to hear part of the sermon. It was addressed principally to the mourners. crumbs of comfort. Hannah is quite worn out  Have not seen her yet to speak to her since DO's death. This morning I stopped a few minutes. She was still sleeping I believe, at least she had not risen. Dear Cousin 

  Received your letter on our way to the Depot. We are just arrived in Brooklyn i e  Lizzie and I - brother Thomas is to be buried in Greenwood Cemetery in a plot of his own choosing 

in great haste from your affectionate Cousin 

  Charly 

Funeral to take place next Sunday afternoon - Brother Robert is well and sends love &c

Remsen N.Y. 
 Saturday Oct. 21. 

My Dear Aunt Anna 

 You see that grandmama and I are in Remsen. I am over at your house waiting to go to the village with Aunt Mary and Grandmama is down at Aunt Jane's. 
  We have some wonderful news - Dottie has a ten pound boy and we are so excited we hardly know where we are. The Baby (whose name is to be John

Theodore) was born on Thursday morning at half past five. Mama is with Father so grandmama and Jane are here for a visit. Thursday evening Dotties baby cried for the light  Think of it--he was not a day old!
Just as soon as the nurse put out the gas the baby began to cry and when she lit it he stopped, he did that two or three times and then Dottie said he must get over it so they left the light out.
Clarence (my baby brother)

thinks that the new cousin isnt much good because he couldnt come down to breakfast Thursday morning.
Dottie is very well indeed and really looks just like herself.
The country is lovely now--just cool enough to be pleasant.
Aunt Mary is waiting so I will stop.  
With much love
from
Bessie Williams
408 N George St
Rome
N.Y.

Dear Cousin
Will you please see that this package reaches its destination? Mama & I send it with our best wishes for the future happiness of Frank and his intended bride.
We are all very well, with the exception of colds, from which we all are suffering more or less. Mama is very anxious indeed to have you come down next week and stay a week or two, I believe

she said if you could come the 16th you could attend four lectures in two weeks. If you do not attend Frank's wedding can't you come the 16th? I do hope you will come the next day if you cannot that, for Mama is almost sick today, she is so homesick for some of you to come down; and she has made up her mind that it is to be you.

Stellapolis Sept -29 1871  
To Anna & Cynthia 
Dear Friends

 Do not be surprised at receiving this from me after so long a delay on my part I meant to write to you immediately after receiving the letter you wrote at fathers but put it off for a day or two and putting things off dont get them done. Well Cynthia your letter did me good beside giving me much pleasure at the time. And my dear Anna I was very much pleased to learn you are so much stronger than you used to be only think when

you came to Rome three years ago you could not go to church once then I would consider it a great priviledge now to be able to go to the church I used to go to in Rome. but must make the best of it I like Mr Price very much and we miss him very much now that he is about. we go to the English Congregational occasional they have a very nice little minister there but he is not very deep as a preacher. We are having delightful weather here but very dry. One great fault with this place is there are not many woods in sight though we are more favored than many in that respect as some of the woods along the crack are in sight from here and then all the old settlers

have groves by their houses I can see two or three from here I wish there was one by this house then I think I could imagine it romantic here. We have 3 quite near neighbors here. as near as your nearest I have been housekeeping since about the 20. Amy and get along very well (I think) and would like it very well if I  was only somewhere near home I have homesick spells. otherwise I am very well my health is much better then it used to be Yesterday I went with my nephews & neice to the Co fair at Marengo a distance of 12 miles it took us about 2 hours to go that distance the roads are quite smooth and level and we had a

gay time going and coming  if the fair was not much they had some good horse trading there I felt quite interested as it was a horse I used to ride that was the premium he was my nephews horse. I continue riding horseback but it will soon be to cold You have had your Cymanfa there some time ago and a very good one it was I heard. they are going to have one here after Mr. Price returns. Well I will close this unintersting epistle

David sends his kind regards to you but I send love ever so more to you two. and all your folks please excuse all errors and write to me soon. 

Your Sincere Friend 
Mary

I dare say you will  be somewhat surpryzed, when you  receive these hasty lines, to find that  I am still in New York = It was all  false reports that were in the papers.  so I intended if well; to start on Saturday next, with the steamer City of Washington she was to start today - but delayed until Saturday, to carry the Mail - as she is reckond an excellent one I hope any-way we will cross safe

and quick = for you know how anxious I am to see my only dear Brother alive - & what a trial it will be to me - ifI should find he was put in the cold grave = But, I must submitt to the will of God; He doeth all things well - It, is true the body is weak, but if we give ourselves entirely to the care of God, he has promised - that he will not forsake us, that he will give, us strength according to our day = Pray for me After I left you, my Dear Friends I was very, ill indeed, owing perhaps to my rest been disturbed, And perhaps my exertion to go to the falls = We reached Elmira about 1 oclock in the morning, but was ten minutes, too late for the Cars, that went to N.Y.  had

to wait until 1/2 5 in the Morning, at a pleasant sitting room , in a Hotell close by - I was afraid of taking a room , so I might rest a little; and I suppose , it arose from that - for I was so resolved to reach N.Y. in time as I thought then = but am happily to inform you, that I met with other kind friends; after you - but I did not feel offcourse as near to them , as to you , I don’t know, what I should have done only for them= but towards afternoon felt some better, but tired I assure you And if there was a steamer going next day I don’t believe, I could have started for it would be a great risk for me the way I felt

I hope you all reached home safe, and found your dear Mother , And all well I presume your kind & tender Father felt much fatigued = I shall never forgett his kindnesses to me, & yours the same Forgett, indeed. I shall think of them. [?] forgett. I beg of you, to write by return as I promised - for it will , I assure you, fladder me, in the midst of my many sorrows- dont disappoint me, my Dear friend and I will answer by return with lots of news, that will interest you = how is your dear Sister, my love to her, and ask for me, if she has been left, yet or since, by the boat - I have many times, I have wished for you both since in N.Y. [?] you were going with me across the deep waters. By the by how is Mr P. Williams my kind regards to him = And please ask him = (If he dont think, it is getting late). How is Miss Williams Excuse all, for I am in haste to write to all, from Your ever loving friend and well wisher Elizabeth Pierce

Remson Dec 23d 1857
Dear Anna
Pardon my seeming neglect in not answering your kind letter er'e this. I intended when I received it to write immediately but my school occupies so much of my time that this is the first leisure time I have had since its reception.
I was very sorry that I did see you again before you left.  I thought you wait until noonday. I am getting along nicely with my school, I have but one week longer of this term. I will have a week or two vacation. I really wish you could come in here some afternoon,

to see as you say how I manage affairs. you would find me very strict indeed. I am so sorry your sister is not here to teach this winter. I had though so much about going to school this winter. Autumn has been here and left traces of its cruelty upon our trees, and vines, the leaves have all deserted them and lie scattered about our yards and walks, making our houses appear gloomy and desolate enough, but it has also brought with a great abundance of fruit. I presume you have a great quantity there also. I am sorry you were not here to attend the big meeting. We had excellent meetings. I like the Rev. Samuel Roberts very much. Reading the description of your room makes me long to be with you. Those trees by each window must make it appear quite romantic and that pleasant-walk that you spoke of that leads to the gentlemen's cottage. I presume you have taken many pleasant walks upon it. Is'nt Galesburg the

place where all who go get married. If so, I suppose that in about a year Miss Anna L. Everett will return Remsen a Mrs. So and So, then your sister Sara and myself are to go there to try our luck so I just wish you would hurry if we are to wait until you are married but we will try and wait very patiently.
Peirce's school was out last week but I suppose that is no news, I thought he intended to teach all winter, but I presume he feels so badly he can not teach since you are not here. unclear you ashamed to break the poor boy's heart. I have been to your house but once since you left. Ellen and myself went up there one afternoon a few days before Lizzie left. I am sorry her health is so poorly. I delivered your message to the girls, they in return wish to be kindly remembered to you both. Please tell your sister that this letter is intended for her also and I should be pleased to have her 
answer it. I must soon close after first begging you not to delay as long as I did in writing, you should always return good for evil. I intend to. Give my love to your sister and reserve a large portion for yourself. Love ever dear friend, Kate?

For your dear eyes alone.
Racine, January 14th 1839
Dear Anna,
I doubt whether you will forgive me for my very long silence, I humbly ask for you to do so. Don't forget the old proverb vis: If you don't forgive others you break the bridge, over which you will want to pass yourself.
Well Anna dear, you looked for my visit in vain after all the anticipations, but so the world goes. I did expect to come when father came, but his coming without me was no great calamity after all to me

as I would not of engaged myself at that time. "circumstances alters the case." sometimes.
They promise to let me come next summer, but I shall not dream and think to much of it, for fear I shall be disappointed again. It would be great pleasure.
I am taking music lessons now, and people tell me I shall sing myself "out" soon but I don't agree with them for I think it keeps my big self alive. We have singing schools every week, and also, temperance meetings every month where we sing temperance pieces. Mrs. Williams the singer that sat next to me dressed in black has last her little girl, that pretty little girl. And Mrs. Griffith has had a baby, so you see I

have to exert myself more on account of the babies, "the little dear"
Mrs. Williams the "store" lost that that fine little fellow I spoke of in a few weeks. I am going to try to have that Harmalam of theirs, but the times are so hard.

  My Aunt Ellen has been keeping her bed for months but is better now, she has just been down in the city. Aunt Laura has moved to Mrs. Jane's house. Widow used to be, but is wife now and gone away, where we spent the afternoon and Mr. G. Sl. W. gave us the pleasure of his company. 
  Annie James is married to her old lover, Johnny and W? Ann are together as often as possible just as loving. Anna Owen's family have moved from here and I did not see? her but speak to her after you

left. Charles Lewis came home soon after you went away, and felt bad that he did not see you. He is now teaching school in the country. He is a pretty nice fellow.

  Dear Anna I don't think you will a better newspaper for a while do you? but I must now close of a necessity. I have an excellent stepmother and I feel to some degree happy is not the same quite. She sends her love to your parents so does also Joe and Father to you all. Give my love (which is very warm) to your sisters, brothers and the fat little babies, parents and all. But take all that deer heart of yours can accept from your very sincere little friend Lizzie

P.S. if you love me answer soon, and extend the writing. I was prompted to go and write directly this morning because I dream'nt with you last night. I thought you were going with me to Milwaukee to my wedding. Absurd. And when I was nearly ready for the ceremony you asked me if I would not like to postpone it for awhile. How ridiculous for you to do so Anna how could you. Answer me. Excuse the length. L.G.

March 18th My dear Anna Mary has been “at me”  every day since she wrote to you - for me to write too but I really have not had any time. I learn or at least try to learn these lessons a week in French and entertain company about every day - besides trying to fit Mary’s dresses I am sorry you are losing your piano practice You had better come back and stay awhile with us Mother says tell Anna that she remembers with much pleasure your stay with us and hopes to see you here again soon. I most heartily join in the wish. You will see what I  have written to Jennie. Our drawings are universcally admired and that little unclear you gave me. I am going to get

it framed Mrs. Shaw’s baby is quite sick, with inflamation on the lungs.  I do not know that I am sorry that I am not going from house this Spring to teach. I had not at any time fully decided to do so. We shall be very much disappointed if we do not visit you this summer. Mary intends to go next Wednesday to B. Willie & Callie want to write but they are not here now.

 Good bye and write me soon
     Yours aff
  C. B. R.  

My regards if you please to all of your people -

Canastota Jan 16th 1861 

My dear Anna:

   We really began to be impatient before your letter reached us. The children made a great fuss because Anna did not write. I am over the stone almost as you left me, I have not been as well since. But there is some reason for it. You never saw a gayor little place than this same Quality? Hill has been since you left. People had just become ready for social enjoyment. It was too bad that you were here all through the dull part of the year. The reason which is alluded to above is that I have been out evenings too much. But I am about well again and now have learned that I cannot make a "winter night"of Christmas and


Our people all send love to you and James says to his sisters too. Please remember me to all of your people.

New Year's too without feeling that is most too much of a draft. All of the sleighing we have had was between Christmas and New Years. Our new carpet is down and the change made in this room. It looks well. I have got a new shawl. Black White n Gray. Don't you believe it is gay! Emily is coming home today. She did not come Christmas- but the boys did. Mr. Shaw's? people particularly  - and others were much surprised to find that you had gone and regretted they could not have seen you before leaving, they thought you were going to spend the winter. Tues evening last, I attended a donation for the benefit of Mr Little. It was tolerably pleasant but I can assure you our Quality?-Hill societies surpased it. 

  I have been delaying an

answering your letter, hoping I might have an opportunity of seeing the trustees here in regard to Cynthia. The weather has been so bad together with my indisposition has prevented. I swear to do it soon.

   I hope you will not be without piano practice long. It will be a decided disadvantage if you do. But then, in the language of the old lady- 'one can't do every thing in a minute' and you must hope and work for better times. The children are in school. I expect they will be in high dudgeon when they find I have sent a letter to you without giving them a chance read along too. In fact I believe some of them have something written somewhere.
   Anna, do you answer the matrimonial advertisement that came in 'The Herald' today? Tell Jennie to do it. If I could do it right I would. But I must bid you goodbye. Now Annie do please write me soon.  Yours with much love. G.B.N.

Dear Jennie: The few words you sent along with Annie were very acceptable How sorry I am that you could not have  come to see me when Anna was here But you will come when you can wont You? We miss Anna very much. I do particularly. she is a dear good chick and I used to be so much afraid of her being homesick. Though I know she could not help it sometimes, she never said one word about it. I answered an advertisement the other day , which offered in “The N. Y. Independent” under the head of  teacher wanted. I gave your name as reference in answer to a letter from Miss Wilson requesting references. I hope you will “set me up” as much as you can conscientously and never say one word, that I have written you. However she may not write you. She said she could pay but a small salary and I told her I wanted a pretty good one. I hope you will take good care of Anna and chastise her whenever she needs it and oblige the subscriber -  Write me soon & excuse haste, Aff C. B. N.

Miss. Annie Everet
Galesburg
envelope is embossed with a floral wreath all around

Iowa City, April 9th 1866
Dear Friend Anna
The old adage, better late than never, has prompted me to sit down and write to you. 
It is a year this week since Mother Lewis came here, and brought a token of remembrance and affection from my friend Anna. I intended at the time to write immediately but neglected continually until it was shame that hindered me from doing so. The other day I made up the dress you sent, for Lydia my second little girl, and whilst telling her it was an old friend of mamma's

that had given it to her, I asked her if she would not like to kiss you for it, she said yes and she would hug you hard. Dear friend, it was not because I was ungrateful, or that I never of you that I did not to you before, but simply because I have so many things to take up my time with my little family that is very easy for me to neglect my duty of writing when I should. I felt very thankful to you for your kind token, and very often think of you and many others who I should give must to see. 
I did talk some of coming east this summer, but have given it up for another year, then if life and health is spared I hope to see you, and enjoy your pleasant company. Dear Anna it was a very pleasant time that we spent together at Racine, was it not? I did enjoy your sweet companionship so much notwithstanding the great sorrow, that

was gnawing at my poor heart, you know I had very recently lost my dear dear mother, and expected so soon to see her place occupied by another, it was very hard to bear at the time, but the Lord gave me strength, and He ruleth all things well. It is a great comfort for me now to know that my aged father has a good and kind companion to take care of him. They are both coming here on a visit next month. We shall be very glad to see them and have them with us even for a short time, but it would be a much greater pleasure to have them come here to live again. I do not like to have father so far from me, and my brother also, but he will come West as soon as he is through at West Point.
We as a family are enjoying good health at present, and O how thankful we should feel, and how much we ow to Our Heavenly Father for his great

goodness, and His great forbearance towards us, in sparing our unworthy lives, whilst we are continuously sinning against Him and forgetful of His Holy Will.
I must say that my heart fills with gratitude to Him for his blessings, he has given me a kind loving husband and three sweet children, and hath not broke a link in our family yet. I feel that there is a great responsibility resting upon me as a Christian wife and mother to set the example that I should before my family and bring up my children in the fear of Lord, but I know where to go for strength and grace to aid me, in every time of need.
Grandma Lewis and the girls are well and I believe pretty contented in their western home they moved last week into a very nice house, and they have enough to do, which is just what they want.
Beck has an excellent situation in the best store in the place. It is a great comfort for me to have them here, as I was rather lonely here before. I am Welsh and feel better with the Welsh. I am deprived of Welsh services, but I am beginning to feel more at home with the English. I must close as my sheet is getting filled, with much love to your parents and sisters and brother. and a great share for yourself. Charlie also joins me in love. Your affectionate friend Lizzie L.
I shall know whether I am forgiven if you answer soon, although I can not blame you if you do not. Is there no hopes of seeing you here Anna?

Phila. Aug. 10. 6 8 
Dear Miss A. M. Everett. 
Your note of the 7th inst. is rec’d. I send you at once a copy of our Announcement.

It has never been our practice to recognize the New York. School as equal to our own - or to grauate its students after one course of lectures. I fear we cannot give you encouragement for doing so at present.  Should you desire a more definite reply I  would advise you to write to the Dean of the College Dr. Ann Preston to 1732 Filbert St. Phila. setting

forth the claim you have to graduation &  the date of which you attended the New York  College. 

 We should be happy  to contribute in any way to your facilities for study & for a degree that would not compromise the interest of the school. 
 Wishing soon to hear from you again I am yours truly 
     E. A. Cleveland.

Remsen Dec 16th 1875
Miss Anna Everette
Dear friend
Are you intending to take Arthurs Home Magazine next year I want to take it and Mrs Short, our Ministers wife will take it. If we send together we can get the three copies for $6,50.
I have been hopeing Cynthia could come to see me with some of the rest of your dear people. Give my love to them all.
Your friend
S.G. Mitchell

Parisville, Portage Co, Ohio.
Dec. 30. 1878.
Miss Anna L. Everett.
Dear Madam.
I ought to apologize for my delay in acknowledging the arrival of your package. It came here about a week ago in good condition. 
I feel much obliged for the pictures, and my opinion is, that one copy of the pictures presented with each copy of the Cofiant, would be more acceptable than only your dear Father's portrait in the book. Your sister from New York wrote some time ago, to ask my opinion about having a chapter in English in the Cofiant, on family matters. and I forgot when writing to her, to tell what I had no objection to that plan, and that I believed

such an arrangement would, very probably, enhance the value of the Memoirs to a numerous class to readers.
I have examined several volumes of the Cenhadwr already, and I have marked several articles as worthy of insertion in the Cofiant. I will send you a list of them in a few weeks; not with the least intention of dictating to you what to publish, but as indicating my own opinion. You have many friends to consult with, and I do not wish you to follow my advice, any further than it coincides with your own opinions, and the opinions of your friends.
If any one has been appointed to write of your venerable Father as an opponent of Slavery, I should like to know, that I may not encroach too much on his limits in writing of him as an Editor.
I am, yours respectfully.
D. Davies

Steuben Sept 30th 
     annotation 1880  /annotation

Dear Anna 

  Your letter Sept 17th came Safely, I was aggreeably Surprised on receiving it. I assure  you. Its contents was perused with pleasure. and a good relish left For another. We are exceedingly glad to hear That your health is So much improved. And to hope you may come home a well girl We are all well Mother is looking better. also feeling much better than she did in the Spring and early part of Summer

Dear Anna the day you wrote me I was not making pumpkin pies doughnuts, preserves, nor Jellies, as you imagined But I made a visit to Mr Millers I also made two pails of Sweet pickles. I have not seen any of your Fathers people Since two or three days after you left George &  I went to Charlies and called to your house as we went, passing I was hoping to have Seen Some of your folks to our house ere this but I have not. I am really glad you are having a good visit. and enjoying yourselves So much. I have one request to make Tis this. That you bring me Some little memento from New Hampton Some little pebbles from the brook or a leaf, flower, or Some thing like that; I should hold it dear as coming from the hills of N. H. — I very much

recon on you coming home for I know I Shall see some of you then. as you promised to come and see us on your return I attended the County Fair at Rome last week. It was pretty good. Considering the weather it was rainy and very cold I Staid with Sister in Rome. Fannie took a worsted wreath and a bed quilt to the fair. got a premium of three dollars on the the two articles _ They are well at Sisters and send much love to you & Sarah You ask how brother George is, and if I manage to keep him Straight he is well and carries himself Remarkably Strait. He is not-hard to manage you know,  Oct 1st I am obliged to give this letter  another date, as I

did not finish it yesterday, I was obliged to lay it aside to attend to domestic duties. Tis Tuesday evening, I am a little tired, I have been busy all day, baking ironing, blacking Stoves &c -; It is getting pretty cold, we had a snug frost last night= not the first one by any means - we have had very many this fall, Now dear Anna I will not add any more to this, but will take another Sheet and Say a few things to Sarah I am a hundred times obliged for your kind remembrance of me in writing to me.  
I am faithfully and truly 
your friend 
Sarah Wolfe

Holland Patent Feb. 22nd 1886  

My dear Misses Everett;

 I do not now know when I will be able to come up to Steubin, so. I write to ask you if you will please leave the amt. of my bill for sewing Eight Dollars ($8.00) with R. G. Griffith of Remsen (I have an account with him) and he will give you a Receipt, We are quite well with exception of slight colds; Hope you are enjoying good health. My kind regards to all.
 Mrs. S. D. Jones. 

P.S. I address to Miss Anna; ‘twill be “all right,” will it not?

Binghamton N.Y.  June 8th /91  
My dear Remsen friends;

 Two days ago I recv'd a setain? paper via Syracuse, announcing the death of my dear and well remembered friend Jennie Everette. four words unclear and myself have often spoken of her and Anna and of Remsen. And many a time have I wanted to write, but it has never been done.  Years have gone by

Bertha White is a doctor in N.Y. city 57 E. 79th St.

and changes have come, Death has entered your home and mine, and who of the dear Remsen friends are living I know not. I will address my letter to Anna. My sister lives with me in Binghamton and I have been here since /69.  My dear husband died Dec. 5th 1885. My brother in law George Le-unclear is with us, and we three compose the family. We have a pleasant home and would be glad to welcome

our friend Anna of dear memory to our house. We have often thought and spoken of her and Jennie.  I would like to hear of Jennie, of you, and of all your family, for, be sure that you are not forgotten. Sister Jenny sends a great deal of love and sympathy in which I join. And we thank you that you remembered to send us a paper with the sad news of Jennie's death. She was a noble soul and I trust her health?

was such as to make her life pleasant to her at its close.

 Hoping to hear from you very soon I am 

Sincerely Yours  
C B. Anthony Harlow  
123 Oak St.  
Binghamton N.Y. 
Mary Faersham- unclear Perkins is living in Burlington unclear  Justtine Farnham - Mrs. unclear is living in Galesburg Ill.  
Louise Sanderson-Ayers died about three years ago leaving a family of several girls. They lived in New York City.

44 Steuben. St
  Utica  May 28th 1891

My Dear friends,

      Miss Anna and Dr Mary 

Was supprised and sorry to see the death of your dear sister Jennie in the Herald
Would have been up to the funeral had I been able to come. I received an injury 14 months ago and am still

oblige to walk with one Crutch I have such pleasant thought of our dear Jennie in meeting the Father Mother and Brothers and Sister and no deafness there, all can hear and all joyious with their Savior that died for all. What a happy change for your dear Sister Jennie I know just how you are going to miss your dear Sister Jennie, 
With Love and Sympathy 
from your old Friend

Phebe Michaels

Ravenwood April 20/93  
Dear Anna

   I am unclear to  write to you but realy I am on the go  so much that I hardly have time to write to home Aunt Jennie has written three letters to me and I am ashamed but I did answer her yesterday it has rained here for three days and such offull  winds last night I thought the house would go with the winds

I was very glad to hear from you and I certanly shall come to see you I wish you would send me a postal if you come here  Well about the suit stout people wear them with yahn? and gather them around the yoke? and higher However I think it would look better for Mary than the collar Mrs Schuler the lady that lives here is very stout and she is goin to get her one like this She said it is the broad-cloth that is not hemed on the bottom or some heavier cloth she thinks

that does not need it I suppos you are tired of waiting for this for she could of had it and wore it about out but you know how it is when you are away from home. The bouquet is very pretty you sent me and it is very fragrant yet. I have heard from him about twice a week Allie is got the measles Gen. Becraft has burried his father Thursday He was taken with bleeding from the nose and they had to stop up his nose and throat he suffered some-thing offall

The rest of the father are all well as far as I know Are you feeling pretty well this spring. I went to the Fair last week and you would immagine you had found a new country and the buildings are some-thing grand from the out side we could not see much except the different buildings there is so much work to be done yet I dont see how they expect to get thrgh so soon hope to heer from you with love to Mary & yourself from Minnie?

Lewisburg Nov 17/94. 
Dear Miss Everett, 
You will be surprized no doubt to hear from me. I have often thought of writing to you but have put it off from time to time. I am not sure whether I even wrote to you or not after I left Remsen, however it does not make much differince whether I did so or not. I very often think of the summers I stayed with you & of all the  things connected with & how terribly broken hearted I was. I think now that perhaps that discipline was just what (in the dear Fathers sight) I needed to curb my haughtiness. Do you remember how I used to gather wild strawberries for you after dinner & how much pleasure I took in your happiness. I loved you very dearly in those days & I will never forget them. But ah; how my pride used to suffer when we had company

I will never forget it. I can see every part of the dear old place now & the library where I used to live to go just to look at the books. Do you remember the first night after your niece left you had a hemmorrhage and I was so frightened, & helpless? I am so glad that your health has so wonderfully improved. Do you remember one night my saying that I would have a college education if I was fifty years old when I started well I am not quite so aged & here I  am at Bucknell University. I can scarcely realize it so earnestly have I longed for it to come to pass. I will be four or five years going through the college & will take up the Latin division of the Scientific Course I do sincerely hope you will write to me before very long, as I will anxiously await your reply. I am working very hard just now

Having entered rather late in the term I have much back work to do in order to catch up. but I can do it very easily between now & Christmas. Will you kindly give me Mr John Eddy’s address, I would like to write to him, I remember how very kind he was to me at that time when my heart was so bitter towards every body Ah; no one can ever understand what I suffered that summer in my foolish, head strong pride, but it  is over now & I look back upon it with a certain degree of pleasure, You will write to me will you not Miss Everett? it will give  me such great pleasure. I shall await anxiously your reply, and until then believe me to be for the sake of “Auld Lang Syne” 

Your’s very truly 
 M. Alice Thomas.

address me
Miss M. Alice Thomas.
Bucknell University
Lewisburg
Penna.
(Institute.)

Friday Eve April 28./93
Dear Aunties
We were favored with the reading of Aunt Mary's letter last Eve
We were glad to here you were well and anticipating a visit to the Worlds fair I hope you will have a good time
Mary Ann is thinking of going home this summer. She intended to go in May but the rates are not reduced much yet She says she would wait awhile if she knew she could go cheaper by & by The weather is so much colder there than here that she doesnt want to go late it in if all
We are having cold wet weather at present It look now as though we would have a storm to-night

I do dread the storms in the west
Mrs Orin Ls and three children were here this afternoon 
The baby is a very small child
It is three months old
We have sunday school at the school house every sunday at 8 Am 
Mrs Patterson superintendant
We hope it will be a success
Our neighbours say they have vied to have sunday school here a good many times but always failed
We have two colored boys working for us Robert has been planting corn to-day He is afraid he will have to plant a good deal of the land over again as we had a very heavy rain about a week ago I must close as It is bed time much love from all to both familys or do you posses? one if so so much the better 
Write soon Libbie

Home March 24th

Dear Anna,

     Edward has finally consented to let me write for him, he thought he must go up to the store and write a letter to you, he has really is not able he has been on the couch a good share of the day, think if he stays in tonight he will be better.  Tomorrow, he hasn't

P.S. It is uncertain whether whether Mr. Hughs will go tomorrow morning or later

  nate?

any appetite and is weak. He wished me to say that he cut off 10 yds. and thought that would be enough, if it isn’t he will send what you want by mail. The children are quite well now Carroll oftin speaks of his Aunties. Charlie talks considerable and is full of fun. I was in hopes that  some of you was thinking about making us a visit the finish of next month. We would like to see Sarah & William before they go to Hillsdale. It will be so nice for them to

stay with you while the girls go to N.Y. Mrs. Lloyd has called here twice since I  came from Remsen and she said she  should try and write to Cynthia, I commenced a letter to Frank today. hope to finnish it soon. How is Mother remember me kindly to her. Carroll says with tears in his eyes I havint any Grandpa now Grandpa is dead. When does Sarah expect  to move? It is getting  late and I must close with lots of love to you all I remain your Sister

Jefferson Jan 28th/56  
Dear Cousins Anna & Sarah I want to write you a  partnership letter as just now I’ve considerable to do - and I don’t know when I shall have more leisure Anna need not ask my forgiveness but I hope she will not let so long time lapse before she writes again Cousin Sarah, I thank you much for the few lines you penned - and am well prepared to return all (and may hap more) the love you choose to bestow on me. Are you not able to write regularly? use a pencil or whatever is most convenient for you. I am glad your health is so much improved. Lizzie has told me much about you and so did your sisters when I was with them - and I think

very much and often makes trouble for travelers. 

  Mother has gone to bed and Liz is dozing in the rocking chair - but I will not go yet. I am sorry Mary’s health does not improve? Give her much love from me. If she ever gets well I shall sue her for the letter she owes me. but forbear at present in pity for her hand. My sister is still at the Glen I hope she will visit youbefore her return but I don’t know what her plans are. Give very much love to Aunt, Uncle Cynthia, Eddie and the others- not forgetting old Tom? for I enjoyed any rides after him very much. What has become of the blind man? Lewis Thomas or Thomas Lewis I think his name was Well the fire is almost out - the good folks are preparing for bed and so must I - Much love to you both and plesant dreams. Good - night. 
 Ottie R

have said anything against the stones though I do think prairie grass is a great deal better. The Aki? you sent I put beneath our pillows and though we tried very much we didn’t dream anything remarkable or very distinct= I should Like very much to attend singing-school with you - though we have one twice each week just across the road from our house - Jefferson is a very quiet place and singing-schools are about all the excitement we have- with now and then a dance - but the last I do not attend you ask if we know anything about New York snow storms in Illinois as a general thing since any rememberance we have had very little snow - only a few inches in depth and that only a part of the time, but last year I should think from Fathers story New York was scarcely ahead of us - This winter eve have a great deal of snow and some very  severely cold weather. The snow drifts

I am rather more than half acquainted with you - I have an idea- of your look from your daguerrotype - Mother thinks I resemble Anna - I don’t know whether I shall see you next summer or not -  I should like very much to come to see old acquaintances and to make some new ones but I  think it is doubtful if I shall- I try to make Lizzie believe she wont go but she says she will just to show me she can. Lizzie has been here sometime and has become one of us - I don’t know how I am to spare her even for “sister Mary” Father calls us ‘Pork and Beans’ because we always go together as those articles do - but we  cannot agree among ourselves which is which - for we are good Hydropaths and Pork is our Abomination  Much love to Lewis and the ‘dear good girl’ who has become his wife. If Lewis had invited me to the wedding I wouldn’t

Remsen June 7th '51
Sister:
You are indeed a dear sister for it takes three and perhaps more letters to get one from you. You must be enjoying yourself nicely I should judge from letters kindly shown me by my friends. I am glad you are satisfied not to do much sewing; it would only waste your strength on what we could as well hire done. Father is in great trouble about getting the Cenhadwr out again. Lewis says he cannot do i tin season with what help he has. Mr. Davis is here today for the first day I think since you left. I have advised pa to write to Utica for help, hope he will be able to get some one. Several subscribers are giving up the "Cen" because it is 
Mother and Father are pretty well though tired. Get us one and a half 1/2 doz lemons to make fries. We like them very much. Sis says we are having a great time cleaning - think "we are having a great time eating." Only think, last Sat we made nineteen fries and now only two are left to tell the sad fate of their friends. If you can, Sarah would like you to get her a yard like her a dress to line the sleeves or else get white silk. Pa has written for a printer! How soon may we ask for a visit from "cousin Mary and family? Love to her and all!

room for next term: as the prospects now are we shall not suffer much from heat. I must pause now and rundown and sew a few sermons.
Anna darling, as Jennie has kindly ranted me this opportunity to write to you I gladly improve it. Thank you much for your letter which I found waiting for me on my return from Mr. Williams. Jennie is now hunting for a pencil and what do you suppose she found in one of her pockets? a piece of graham cracker given her by J.M.J., some of his from make, I believe. A very sentimental memento, don't you think so?
We are having great times housecleaning now days; as perhaps I should say they are having, for I have done but a very little. I was up to Mr. Williams about a week and after returning I have not done much although I feel much better

than before I went. I guess I must wait till I see you before I tell you about my visit. I ment to have written to you and Lizzie last evening but was most too tired. Give my best love to Lizzie and thank her a thousand times for her kind invitations which I hope I shall be able to accept soon I have lots of things to tell her but I am intending to write to her. You don't know how much I want to see you both soon how glad I am that Lizzie intends to come home with me.   I am expecting Sis up to write a little in this so I must hurry. Anna , dont you think you can fit me with a  pair of garters? If you can and if you have money I wish you would get me a pair something like yours.  Wm. Griffith is here whitewashing today so you can imagine something of our condition. We cleared out fathers study yesterday and day before, and O, what a

mess! Jennie and Sis papered it: you may see how it looks when you come home. By the way Anna, how do you get along with music? Does he let you play any tunes? Sarah seems to think music has great power over you, else why should you ask his permission to play tunes. How gratified I am to you dear Anna for so kindly permitting me to write to you. You do not know what a self-denial it was, for me being long without writing you. Thank Lizzie very much for her letter, I will try to answer it soon. I am glad she has written to "cousin Henry", but do not think she need fear he will not "take" How delightful must be the hours of night to you, when soft music fills the air, and peaceful moon beems float around, and kindred hearts hold sweet comuneion!   Where did you attend church Sunday? Have you heard Mr. Price preach yet, and if you have how do you like him? I am glad you have got such a good opportunity to practice. Has any one told you how many visitors we have had this vacation year, fear they have not. I will tell. Last week. Mon. Ruth Celia Maria & Nansie made us a call, almost long enough for a visit. Wednesday, I believe, Isabel, Lucy, and Nany Manuel, were here.They came a little while before dinner, and staid till about four o clock, and Saturday afternoon, Maggie and Libbie, and Mary and Hetty Roberts made us a visit. I wend a little way with them home, and Mary Roberts and I went in and explored the wonders of Hannah Roberts old house the famous haunted house. We saw no ghosts however. You have doubtless read in the papers of the mysterious atmospheric body that produced such disastrous effect in Sherfield and elsewhere. Did you see or hear it at the time? We can not but feel grateful that though it passed over the city, it did no harm to our loved ones there, - Have you seen the comet yet? We have not, but have heard it could be seen in the daytime through smoked glass. - Don't be worried about the Cen. Pa says he does not want Anna to come home. - So there - take all the comfort and pleasure you  can with your music, and rest yourself during this little vacation. - Thank Lizzie most kindly for my part of Sissies letter, the envelope that I suppose belongs to me as my name is on it. - How could Lizzie be so thoughtful, as to remember one who is so negligent in writing to her! - By the way, I hope Lizzie will come home again before long. - I am felling no worse since coming home. 
We are having a grand time cleaning house, have papered the parlor Pa's study and Lewis' rooms. Lettie came home Sunday not feeling very well, went back today feeling better!

Osawatomie, Apr, 9, 1891

Dear Aunt Anna,

     Aunt Jennie wants me to write to you to day as she is not feeling first-rate

We received a letter from Aunt Mary yesterday they were well she seems to be enjoying her visit, 
Uncle John has got his teeth & is doing very well with them we think It is very warm to day
The grass is beginning to look green and some kinds of trees are beginning to leave out we have had a great deal of rain lately so the ground has been too wet to put in a crop
Much love from all, write soon,
Libbie
